summary: Gaeton Fonzi was a staff member of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The documents indicate that in May 1978, Fonzi, along with Albert Gonzales, visited Guayaquil and Caracas as part of the HSCA's investigation. A CIA station in Guayaquil reported on their upcoming visit and requested guidance on potential contact. Later, in August 1995, Fonzi's name appears in a cable discussing a meeting in Rio de Janeiro involving Cuban CI officers and alleged CIA officers, where the JFK and Letelier assassinations were reviewed. This suggests Fonzi's work with the HSCA involved investigating the JFK assassination, and his name continued to surface in discussions related to the assassination years later.
significance: Gaeton Fonzi's significance lies in his role as a staff member of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), actively involved in investigating the JFK assassination. His visits to places like Guayaquil and Caracas as part of the HSCA investigation highlight his direct involvement in gathering information related to the assassination. The later mention of his name in connection with a meeting reviewing the JFK assassination suggests a continued interest or relevance to the topic.
